div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.dateline: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1830. Editor and Manager: R. Snelling« One Piastre Tariff MONDAY. MARCH 20, 1905.
div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: The Government has decided not to heighten the Assouan Dam in the meantime, and as a corollary, not to sell, or grant in concession, any large blocks of free State lands. Sir William Garstin, in fall accord with Sir Benjamin Baker, has come to a momentous decision, and the Council of Ministers has adopted the conclusions arrived at We are told that scholiasts have evolved new theories to prove that a dam might be safe as regards cracking horizontally, but nevertheless be liable to crack vertically. We are also told that a good deal of protective work must be undertaken down-stream of the sluices. The public have been told all they need know. It is enough to justify the decision arrived at against heightening the dam meantime. Sir William Willcocks’ opinion, frankly expressed, can be best described as calling it funk on the part of Sir Benjamin Baker, and in so doing affords a singular instance of freedom from restraints of office. Our excellent confrere the "Phare d’Alexandrie” says people believe that the report of Sir Wm. Garstin conceals an able manoeuvre to check speculation in land,to the encouragement of transport facilities. Government need not employ deep-laid schemes to develop transport. If this were their aim it could be achieved by | less jealous obstacle-raising to the development of the Delta Light Railway, and by respecting possible and past navigation channels for the smaller class of boats. The desire to check land speculation is laudable, but a Government can do much harm by interference with economic laws. The British financial world is casting longing eyes on Egypt, and. will have the land as surely as jt took the Transvaal goldfields. The prohibition of all Large sales of Government land is too drastic. The result will be increased theft of Mariout lands by fictitious Bedouin sales, and transactions on doubtful title of inferior lands elsewhere at high prices. We are promised a study, of storage schemes other than heightening the dam, and contemporaneously with this study there might be study of reclamation methods on small selected areas. Sir Will Wllcocks advocates small basin reservoirs in the Delta, and there is no earthly reason why he should not be allowed to make the experiment. Other people advocate the use to drainage water for reclamation purposes, and are prepared to back their opinion by costly experiment. Artesian water may yet be found in Egypt, and , every encouragement should be given to those who will undertake such an expensive risk as boring to great depths. There are a million and a half feddans of waste land in Egypt, and Government have a sacred trust in seeing that it does not fall into the hands of capitalists for the mere asking. That trust is equally abused if the talent is tied up in a napkin. It is pusillanimous to stop all advance in reclamation because theorists question formula; for calculating masonry dams, and it is weak to say if Government grant anyone laud for experiment others will expect the same treatment It is in the interacts of Egypt that in anticipation of farther summer supplies of Nile water, lull experiment should meantime be allowed of rival reclamation systems. Then Government will have some data to go on when the time comes to deal with the waste State lands. A Government so desirous to protect the public should see that land is neither given away, nor sold at prices disastrous to the investor. A great deal of the outcry about scanty summer water would cease if the whole of Lower Egypt were not now being put under summer crop. Restriction of rice cultivation, and a permanent decree forbidding the sowing of maize till July 20, would instantly result iu the present summer supply being ample. Gross abuses have crept into file use of summer and should be peremptorily checked. It is a solution of the present difficulty which we submit to Government as an alternative course preferable to stopping all agricultural development in Egypt.

div.head: JAPANESE ADVANCE, CONTINUED FIGHTING. KAI-YUEN OCCUPIED.
div.p: Tieling, March 18. The lighting continues unabated 30 miles to the North. The Japanese are pressing on both flanks. (Reuter.) St. Petersburg, March 18. Fighting is continually taking place in the rear-guard. The Russians, notwithstanding their fatigue, are keeping the enemy in check. (Haras.) Tokio, March 18. The Japanese, after having driven the Russians out, have occupied a height to the north of Tiding on the right tank of the Liao. (H.) St. Petersburg, March 19. The Japanese occcupy Kai-Yuen. The population of Kharbin, who are driven frantic, expect to see the Japanese on April 10. ( Havas.) Tokio, March 19. The Japanese, have occupied Fakumen, to the north west of Tieling. (Reuter.) Tieling, March 20. he Japanese have reached Kai-Yuen, 23 miles to the North. The Russians evacuated the town on Saturday after having set fire to the station (Reuttr.) London. March 20. Reuter's correspondent with Kuroki says that on the 13th inst. the repairs to the Hunho bridge were almost completed. Trains will to Mukden and beyond within a week. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADVANCE TO HARBIN ADVOCATED.
div.p: The conservative element in the high councils here which formerly opposed the advance on Harbin is now in favor of pressing the advantages home, aud carrying forward the war to its utmost limit..

div.head: THE CHANGE IN THE COMMAND.
div.p: It is confirmed that General Kuropatkin has started, and that Linievitch has assumed the command. (Reuter.) Generals Kuropatkin and Linievitch telegraphed to the Tsar yesterday respectively resigning and assuming the supreme command, in accordance with His Majesty’s orders. (R.)

div.head: RUSSIAN PRESS AND THE WAR.
div.p: The press is changing its tone and now demanding the prosecution of the war. It praises Kuropatkin’s energy and determination in the face of overwhelming difficulties, and approves the appointment ot Linievitch. (R.)

div.head: STOESSEL TO BE TRIED.
div.p: A commission has been appointed uuder the presidency of General Roop to investigate the circumstances regarding the capitulation of Port Arthur, aud to try Geueral Stoesael. (R.)

div.head: RUSSIA’S GOLD RESERVE.
div.p: It is officially anuounced that Russia’s gold reserve yesterday was 1,349,000,000 roubles, and the circulating credit notes 903,000,000. The amount legally required to cover the latter is only 602,000,000. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN LOAN.
div.p: Negotiations with the bankers for an in terual loan at 5% of 200,000,000 roubles have been virtually concluded. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE JAPANESE LOAN.
div.p: If satisfactory terms can be arranged, a number of New York bankers are ready to participate with the German financiers in bringing out a Japanese loan. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: Renter’s Agency learns from Antananarivo that Admiral Rodjestvensky’s squadron left Nossi B£ on Thursday afternoon for an unknown destination. (Reuter.)

div.head: END OF MULLAH TROUBLES ARRANGEMENT COME TO
div.p: The Italian Agent has concluded at Illig an agreement with the Mullah, acting on instructions received from the Italian Government and also in the interests of Great Britain. The latter promises to maintain a general peace. He will take- up his residence in territory belonging to the Italian Protectorate and assigned to him by agreement. Here he will he free to enter into commerce except as regards the traffic of arms. Slavery will be prohibited. Colonel Swayue has expressed his complete satisfaction. (Reuter.)

div.head: DISTURBANCES IN RUSSIA. REVOLUTIONARY ORGANISATION DISCOVERED.
div.p: The mobilisation rumours have caused fresh strikes at Lodz and Warsaw. (Renter.) Moscow, March 19. The secret police here have discovered a revolutionary organisation. They seized a store containing infernal machines, hand bombs, explosives, arms, printing presses, and the correspondence relating to the plot to assassinate the Grand Duke Sergius. 300 arrests have already been made. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE NEVA INCIDENT. SENTENCE OF COURT MARTIAL.
div.p: The Court Martial oh the Neva incident, mentioned on the 19th January, found no malicious intent. Three officers have been sentenced to 18 months’ detention for neglecting their duties, and two gunners to two years in a disciplinary battalion.

div.head: THE QUEEN’S JOURNEY.
div.p: Owing to the rough sea, the royal yacht with the Queen on hoard has taken refuge at Portland. (Reuter.) The Queen has left. AUSTRIA-HUNGARY Budapest, March 19. The Emperor has arrived. {Havas.) FRENCH ARMY Paris, March 18. Both the Chambers have passed the two years’ military service bill. (Reu'er.)

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: Rugby.—Scotland beat England by 8 points to nil. Association.—Scotland boat Ireland by 4 goals to nil. {Reuter.)

div.head: CONSTANTONINOPLE NOTES (From our Correspondent).
div.p: The Romanian Minister of Public Works is to preside at the inauguration of the new line which the Rouinauiau Maritime Service has decided to create between Constanza, Smyrna, and Constantinople-Piraeus. This line will afterwards be extended to Alexandria, and it is proposed also to create a direct service between your town and Constantinople. The Hellenic steam navigation company, “La Phocdenne,” established atAthens with i he object of lorming a line between Athen and Alexandria, has also decided to exteud the service to Smyrna and Constantinople. The Commission for the Hedjaz Railway has received new subscriptions amouuting to P. 287,600, which brings up the general total ol its fund to P. 82,355,689. Mr. Townley, late of the British Embassy at Coustantinople, aud Lady Susau Townley lelt here on Tuesday by the Khedivil mail steamer. They propose visiting Jerusalem and Egypt before proceeding home. Mr. R. E. Weakley, commercial attached to the british embassy, returnined last week from Alexandria.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: No Quarantine in Cyprus.—Free pratique is now granted to arrivals in Cyprus from Egyptian ports. Boat Capsized.—A boat laden with sand was capsized by the strong wind yesterday near Aboukir. The orew were saved. Tourist Steamers.—The White Star liner “Arabic” and the S Y. “Argonaut” are.leaving Alexandria to-day on the continuation of their cruise Cairo Water Co. — Sir Elwin Palmer and Dr. Dacorogna have been appointed directors of the company in place of the late Tigrane Pasha and Mr. E. J. Manuk. The Hired Transport “Plassy,” which is due at Port Said on the 26th inst., homeward bound, takes a number of details of the Army of Occupation for passage home. New Egyptian Company.—The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has appointed Wednesday next as a special settling day for the New Egyptian Co. 250,000 shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 150,000 and 193,880 to 293,879 ; 3,879 shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 190,001 to 193,879. Parcels ex S.S. “Cairo.”—The Post Office annpQuce that the unaddressed damaged parcels, saved from the wreck of the S.S. “Cairo,” will be sold at the Alexandria Post Office by auction to-morrow at 3.30 p.m. Articles will be on view in a building at the back of the Post Office from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. that day. Publications Received.—The last number to hand of the “Graphic” contains excellent illustrations of the recent passage ^through Port Said of General and Mrs. Stoessel. The Bystander” of last week has two pages fall of snapshots taken at Cairo during the season. The number is a very interesting one, containing many special features. Salt and Soda Company.—Mr. John Thirsk, who for ten years has been the technical manager of the Kafr Zayat Cotton Company at Alexandria, has been appointed works manager of the Salt and Soda Company at Kafr Zayat. The appointment of such a highly qualified expert as Mr. Thirsk will be received with geueral approval by the shareholders of the company. The P.0. Children’s Savings Bank, which commenced working a few weeks ago, bids fair to he very successful. From the 1st February to the 15th inst the number of children who made deposits by means of 5-millieme postage stamps reached 1,355. Saba Pasha deserves to be congratulated, for the large total of juvenile depositors appears to show that the scheme has supplied a want The Austrian Lloyd.—Owing to the in. creasing demand for berths, the Austrian Lloyd £>. N. Co. has decided to run two of the best boats as extra steamers to Brindisi, Trieste, and Venice. The S.8. “Salzburg” (3,300 G.T.) will sail from Alexandria on the 23rd inst. at 4 p m. direct for Trieste, and the S.S. “Bohemia” (4,300 G.T.) will sail from Alexandria on the 10th April at 4 p.m. ior Brindisi, Venice, and Trieste. St. Andrew’s Church, Alexandria.—The annual meeting of British residents in connection with St. Andrew’s Church and Harbour Mission was held at LLB.M.’s Consulate on Saturday, Mr. E. B. Gould, I.S.O., in the chair. The financial statement for the past year was submitted, and satisfaction expressed at the sound financial position of the church. Mr. R. Lang Anderson and Mr. John Ross were re elected trustees and Mr. D. Carmichael treasurer for the ensuing year. “THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE.” The second performance of “The Pirates of Penzance,” at the Khedivial Opera House, on Saturday night, was both musically aud finan oially a decided success. There was a large and fashionable gathering present. Mrs. Willmore again sang aud acted excellently. Mr. Webb performed very fairly as Frederick, considering the strain that had been put on his voice in the last performance. Miss Delanoy and Mrs, Nolan also were greatly appreciated by the audieuce. Mr. Trimeu, as the Major-Ge ueral, gave a very good performance in deed. He was one of the few performers we have seen in amateur operetta who knows how to move about the stage naturally. He was a little confused once, when giving the encore verse of the Major-General’s song, but really the verse in question was a little difficult. Capt. Tucker, R.E., gave a very good performance of the Sergeant of Police, and the two encore verses which he sang were enthusiastically received. He had quite got over any of the nervousness which he show ed in the last performance. Of the others, Mr. Serle Peacock, as Samuel, the Hod. C. James, as the Pirate King, and Mrs Merton, as Ruth, played their parts with great spirit, but we did not quite understand the change in Mrs. Merton’s “make-up” in the second act, which was hardly in accord ance with the spirit of the piece. The chorus performed their part very creditably. To turn to the music, Bimbaahi Franklin had considerable difficulty with his orchestra, but succeeded in staving off disaster, which threatened in the second aofc. Dr. Clark, as prompter, and Major Delavoye, as stage manager, deserve oar congratulations for their energy and success. ENGLISH GIRL’S SUICIDE. TRAGEDY AT ALEXANDRIA. A young Englishwoman, of the name of Dora Blake, recently employed as a governess in an English family resident at Ramleh, committed suicide on Saturday at “ Ipswich ” (formerly known as Johnson House), Alexandria. The story of the suicide is a sad one. Miss Blake fell ill a few years ago in South Africa and was treated with cocaine injections. The drug healed her, but left far worse consequences than any which the malady it cured could have done. Cocaine appears to have entirely mastered her, and she became a helpless victim to the habit. It is evident that while under the influence of the effects of the drug she decided to make away with herself, and made an injection strong enough to kill six men. The inquest and funeral took place yesterday. THE NEW HOSPITAL IN OLD CAIRO. An interesting service took place on Friday afternoon, 17 th inst, when the foundation-stone of the “Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital” was laid in the Church Missionary Sooiety’s compound at Old Cairo. About 160 people were present, and, after partaking of tea in the garden, assembled at the spot ohosen, at the south-west oomer of the new building. The Rt. Rev. the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East was present, and, after robing, was preceded to the site by his chaplain, the Rev. N. Odeh, Archdeacon Potter of Cyprus, Dean Butcher, and the.C.M.S. clergy. The Bishop conducted the servioe according to a form whioh had been specially prepared for the occasion, and several of the other olergy took part The actual oeremony of laying the stone was performed by Sir Algernon Coote, Bart (President of the Hibernian C.M.8.), who used in the process a handsome silver and ebony mallet and trowel which had been presented to him by the architect, Mr. A.H. Skyuder, M.S. .C.F. In a short speeoh Sir Algernoon expressed his pleasure at having been asked to lay this stone, and his interest, as an Irishman, in finding that the oeremony was to take place on St Patriok’s Day. He then described the lack of room in the present hospital, the large number of patients, both paying and free, who are treated in it every year, and the circumstances which led to the building of the new memorial wards. Less than two years after her first arrival in Egypt Mrs. Pain had passed away, having laid down her life in the work. Her husband, Dr. Maynard Pain, who had been in charge of the Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney until he joined the C.M.S., is still a member of the society's staff in Old Cairo, and it was from his friends in Australia and New Zealand that subscriptions amounting to £4,800 had been received. No grant has been asked for from the C.M.8. in London, but about £460 has been eeutin donations from England, £127 by residents in Egypt and visitors at the hotels, while the members of the mission have shown their own belief in the value of the work by contributing £76. The money already subscribed is sufficient for ad the building contemplated. The hospital, when finished, will contain beds for about 35 women and children, and the present hospital will then be reserved for men only. There will also be an operating theatre with all the latest improvements, towards which the sterilising apparatus and an operating table have been already contributed. Sir Algernon concluded by saying that a hospital of this sort was one of the best ways of letting our works testify to the value of the faith which will be proclaimed within its walls. Shortly before six o’clock the company dispersed, and, in response to a stfygestion made during Sir Algernon’s speeoh, contributed P.T.923 to a box placed for that purpose at the gate. VENETIAN FETE AT MENA HOUSE. The Mena House trams were orowded on Saturday evening with residents and visitors on their way to the Venetian, whioh proved a brilliant success. The hotel and the gardens were illuminated with hundreds of Chinese lanterns; there was a fine display of fireworks, and the Bedouin fantasia which took place by the police station was greatly appreciated. The dining-room was crowded, and many parties were given before the fete began. Among those who gave dinner parties were H.H. Priuoe Haidar, who had a party of 12, Sir John and Lady Sterling-Maxwell, Mr. Uunard, who had a party of 8, Count Wuls-burg, the Countess Fugger, with a party of 8, and Countess Henkel von Donnersmark, with a party of 5. In spite of the counter-attraction provided by the “Pirates of Peuzanoe/’over 200 residents were there, with many visitors from the other hotels, and though the wind rather interfered with the illuminations at times the whole display went off in a thoroughly satisfactory manner. All the tables were taken for lunoh and dinner yesterday, and among those who lunched in the Oriental dining-room were the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, who were aooompanied by Sir Ernest CasseL ZIZINIA THEATRE. This theatre was on Friday night the scene of a most admirable performance of Michele Perrin, in which Novelli was absolutely incomparable. A high degree of originality and intelligence is put into his acting, and Lis great talents oould find no better aoope for their display. He made a deoided hit in his laughing monologue "Fra un atto 6 l’altro/1 ginn in hit aegustomed style.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: GERMAN LADY’S SUICIDE Port Said, Saturday. A very sad and distressing suicide occurred at daybreak this morning. Mrs. Boysen, wife of a Suez Canal pilot of German nationality, in a state of mental aberration, threw herself from a second-floor window in the Maison Slavick, on the Quay Francois Joseph, killing herself instantly. The deceased, who had been suffering from typhoid fever and pneumonia, asked the nurse in charge to awaken the servant, and it was during her temporary absence for this purpose that the terrible deed was committed. The body was removed to the mortuary at the Egyptian Government Hospital for the enquiry. The funeral took plaoe at 4 p.m. The greatest sympathy is felt for the husband, who is left with four young children.
A NEW DREDGER The “Hastings,” a new dredger built on the Clyde for Rangoon, arrived at Port Said on Friday and left on Saturday morning for her destination.

THE BALTIC FLEET. Port Said, Sunday. Contrary to the expectations expressed in my notes in your issue of yesterday, the Baltio Fleet has not yet arrived here, nor is there any further news of it,' but the general opinion held here is that both the third squadron and the hospital ship “Kostroma,” which passed through the Dardanelles five days ago, have gone to Soda. The proximity of this squadron is evidenced by the presence in our town of the chief Russian secret agent, who arrived from Cairo at 3.30 p.m. to-day.

THE S.8. “PLANET VENUS”. Sues, Saturday. The British steamer “Planet Venus,” whioh grounded in the Suez roads last Wednesday morning, was refloated yesterday evening with the assistance of the tug ‘Titan,” after having discharged several hundred tons of cargo into lightera/which she is to-day reloading. Apparently, the vessel sustained no damage.
THE KHEDIVE. The Khedive spent yesterday at Koubbeb. His Highness will preside at a Council of Ministers on Thursday next at Abdeen Palace.

WARDAN ESTATE CO. The Wardan Estate Company is bringing out a fresh issue of capital, details of which will be found in an advertisement in another column. We have received a copy of the directors’ report to be submitted to the shareholders of the company at their first annual general meeting to be held in Cairo to-morrow. This shows that substantial progress has been made towards the reclamation of the company’s lands; 830 feddans were levelled by cattle up to the 31st December last in spite of cattle plague and consequent difficulty in obtaining cattle. The difficulty is being got over by the purchase of a pair of Messrs. McLaren’s 20 h.p. ploughing machines; more of these powerful engines are to be employed if the working results of the first pair justify it The directors report that the result of last year’s flood is very satisfactory, notwithstanding the poor Nile flood with whioh the Wardan Company, in common with the rest of Egypt, had to put up with. Tree planting has successfully passed the experimental stage. Sufficient trees to plant 360 feddans are ready in pots to be planted out this year. Twenty-seven miles of flood canal, representing more than a million oubio metres of excavation, has been completed and has been provided with regulators and sluices. The directors having satisfied themselves by practical experiment that the system, adopted on the recommendation of Sir William Willoooks, K. C. M. G., for reclaiming these lands is sound and practicable, are now calling up the remainder of the unissued share capital, and have engaged the necessary engineering staff so as to complete the work in the oonrae of the next three years. Like all land reclamation undertakings, time is required before dividends can be paid, but we have little doubt that the shareholders of the Wardan Company who can wait a year or two longer will reap a handsome reward. ALEXANDRIA CENTRAL BUILDINGS CO. This new company, which has been official^ authorised, is to have a capital of £100,000, consisting of 20,000 shares of £5 each. The preliminary articles of association were made between Messrs. Francis Allen, Geo. B. Alder-son, Eecoffier, Wellhoff, Dickson, G. A. Al-dereon, and 0. A. H. Aldereon. The objeots of the oompany are described as follows :—

La Societd a pour objet l’aohat et la vente de terrains et d’immenbles, l’ddifioation et l’exploitation d’immeubles ainsi qne toutes operations se rattachant k oette branohe d’affaires et pouvant contribuer a son ddveloppe-ment. The board of directors oonsists of Messrs. F. Allen, Geo. B. Alderson, Esooffier, and Wellhoff. STEAMER MOVEMENTS. The Moss liner "Pharos” sailed on Friday morning for Liverpool, vik Malta, with paasen gers, mails, and general cargo, including 404 bales ootton. The Cunard S.S. “Brescia” sailed for Liverpool on Saturday with a full oargo. The Messageries Mari times 8. 8, “Congo,” from Mar-ill—, is due at Alexandria to-mar- tow morning'

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Hon. Darea Canon, Lord Zouohe’s sister and heir-presumptive, is in Cairo. Mr. Henry Pearoe, J.P., is staying at the Savoy Hotel, having oome to Egypt for a holiday and rest He is a well-known traveller in Sooth Africa and takes an active interest in politics. Daring the Boer war he joined the Intelligence Department as special servioe offioer and was the oommeroiaf adviser to the Military Governor of Orange River Colony (Sir G. T. Prettyman), afterwards acting Director of Civil Supplies for the 0. R. C., whioh position he resigned in 1902. Our Amerioan and Canadian visitors will be pleased to know that Mr. Monroe, for many years manager of the Bank of Montreal in Chicago, is paying another visit to this oonatry and is staying at the Grand Continental Hotel. div.head: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.
div.p: Sir,—The official explanation given in the “Gazette” of Saturday in regard to the strictures of the International Chamber of Shipping on the could not of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration in the case of the foundering of the Florio-Rubattido SB. “Cairo,” does not dear up all the difficulties — to the responsibility for the disaster. In the first pis—, it is said that the captain of the steamer same within the pivot buoy, and, being an experienced hand at entering the port of Alexandria, he without a pilot on hoard should have either steamed up to the quarantine anchorage or else let go his anchor in the neighbourhood of the pivot buoy. He would then no doufithavejot a pilot within hslf-an-hour or/ say, an hour. Failing that it should have waited until daylight Had he wished to remain outside the harbour, he could have anchored anywhere within half-a-mile of the Bough Pass, by keeping his leading lights in one and steering in that course. The book of Admiralty directions to the port of Alexandria is quite dear to any stranger who approaches the port at night and that coupled with the most excellent leading lights’ and the breakwater fight should have enabled the captain or even a stranger to enter the port without a pilot with the greatest of ease. How the ship managed to fetch up ou the Agame shoal, when the leading fights can be seen on a dark night with a dear atmosphere for seven or eight miles, it is difficult for any navigator to understand. The pilot boats are in the habit of lying on a calm night either at the Tiviot wreck bnoy or else lying well outside in deep water, quite dear of the Agame shoal. There is therefore no excuse for any navigator entering the port of Alexandria at night to mistake probably a fidring boat off the Agame shoal for a pilot boat Another point I should like to point out is that as the Ports and Lighthouses Administration’s powerful.tug “Teir el-Mina” is not fitted with water-tube boilers, it is impossible to raise steam within six hoars unless a great deal of barm be done to the boilers. If the Administration had had any other tog-boats available no doubt assistance would have been sent at onoe. But taking into consideration the state of the sea and swell, it was impossible for any boat, tug-boat or otherwise, to get dose up to the “Cairo” until the morning. In my humble opinion the official who is responsible for the port of Alexandria and the interests thereof is the Captain of the Port I have been informed that this official, on hearing the pews, ordered steam at once to be got up on the “Tdr-d-Mina,” but owing to the state of the weather found that it was impossible to get alongside. However, the next morning the “Teir el Mina,” towing three boats, went out to the soene of the wreck in order to save both passengers and mails, and, if necessary, the baggage. The “Cairo” had a list ot 45 degrees to starboard and it was therefore impossible to save any baggage. One mail-room, on being opened, was found to have had its oontents all washed away. 1 have read a great many allegations in some of the local French papers on the subject of the dangers of the port of Alexandria apropos of the wreck of the “Cairo.” In my opinion as an experienced navigator of this port, and of many other ports also, Alexandria is one of the best-lit ports in the whole of the Mediterranean, and therefore there ought to be no excuse for any man responsible for the navigation of a ship to deviate from his oourse except in oaae of fog. Even in the latter case there is very little margin for exouse when the hand lead can be used within seven mil— of the ooast between Marsa Matrouh and PortBaid. I may oonolude the—- few remarks by., expressing a wish that in future navigators, when entering the port of Alexandria by night or by day, will read, mark, learn,and inwardly digest the book of Admiralty directions, which every efficient navigator ought to have, and of oourse, at the same time, pay careful attention to the ohart If this advice be followed, there oan be no possible difficulty in entering the port of Alexandria or any other port—I am, eto, “Navigator.”

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Major Scott Elliott, Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders, late second in command of the 2nd Battalion at Pretoria, has been 'promoted Lieutenant-Colonel commanding the 1st Battalion at Dublin. The new chief of. the old 79th is well known in Egypt where he served for a considerable time. He was with the Camerons at the routing of Arabi from Tel-el-Kebir’s trenches, the Nile Expepedition 1884-5, and he commanded the Cameron detachment of the Camel Corps in the operations on the Sudan frontier 1885-6. Captain Bertram W. Y. Danford, Royal Engineers, lately employed at the School of Military Engineering,* has been specially selected for service with the Egyptian Army. There are just a dozen officers of the sappers employed with the Khedivial forces. The report of the Director of the Recruiting and Organisation for 1904, just published, shows that the number of recruits who joined the regular army exclusive of Colonial Corps was 41,279, and the Militia recruits 35,624. pi the latter, 15,648 joined the regular army and 792 men who enlisted for Colonial Corps. A total number 71,699 men presented themselves tor enlistment, and out of these 24,658 were /ejected—18,816 tor various ailments aid 5,842 to poor physique. The report, emphatically states that the regulation requiring a character on enlistment has materially raised the tone of the army and popularised it amongst the better class of the people.

Uncle Sam's short ride has also proved a dead failure—like our own. It was to be a lick-creation rifle with the cutest little cleaping rod bayonet ever devised. The lesson in the Far East, where the little Japs have not only withstood magazine ride fire,-but pushed home their assault with cold steel, has not been lost on the Washington officials, who are now devising a longer bayonet. It is to be hoped that our own officials will take the hint It has been decided to increase the Royal-Naval Reserve by permitting seamen of four years’ service to be transferred to it on payment of the proportion of their discharge money. Men of eight years’ service can transfer free. The Royal Marines are included in this but stokers and higher ratings are excluded. The order will remain in force during the financial year of 1905-6, at the end of which it will be reported upon.

div.head: UM RUS Gold Mines
div.p: The directors of the Um Kus Gold Mines of Egypt propose to issue 30,000 new shares to $1 each, thereby raising the capital of the company to £ 180,000, and in a circular which has been sent out conveuiug the necessary meeting for the consideration of the resolution they express the opinion that the scale of operations should be extended, with the ultimate object of increasing the number of stamps and erecting a cyanide plant for the recovery of the gold from the tailings. These shares will be offered at par in the first instance to the existing shareholders at the rate of one new share for every five shares held, payable as follows :—5s. per share on application, 5s. per share on allotment, and the balance in calls not exceeding 5s. per share allotment of not less than three months. The directors hope that each- shareholder will avail himself of this opportunity of increasing his holding in the company.

The proposal to increase the capital has been sanctioned by the Egyptian Government. The light railway from the harbour of Imbarak to the mine, about five and a-half miles in length, has been completed, and a locomotive installed carriage of machinery and stores to the mine is much facilitated thereby. The company owns a steamer, which brings machinery and goods from Suez to Imbarak. By this means shipments from England are made expeditiously and economically. To facilitate the landing of goods a* substantial jetty, 157 ft. long, has been constructed. A crane has been fixed thereon, and goods are lifted out of the lighters direct into the railway trucks. At the harbour the electrical power station is practically complete. Two 150-k.w. generators have been installed, and power will be transmitter! Then mine to drive the air compressor, hauling gear, and other plant The mill has been erected at a convenient site close to the power station, and necessary boilers to supply the steam required to drive the electrical machinery and mill engine are completed. The air compressor has been designed to work ten rock drills, with the object of opening up the reef with greater rapidity. It is estimated that there are about 9,000 tons of ore already in reserve.' For the purpose of considering the proposals an extraordinary general meeting has been convened at the Cannon Street Hotel to-day. The “St James’s Gazette” remarks :— We do not see any reason why the proprietors should rush to take advantage of the ' occasion. The directors are of opinion that the Beale of operations should be extended by an increase in the number of stamps and the erection of a cyanide plant. But there seems no immediate hurry for this, since there are only about 9,000 tons of ore in reserve, or about enough to keep the present stamps going for nine months.

div.head: PILGRIM'S TESTIMONY
div.p: We have received the following letter, which bears every appearance of being a genuine testimony to the excellence of the arrangements of the Quarantine Board. We publish it without amending the English of the original:— To the Director of the 15th Eygptian Gazette. Dear Sir,— I have the honor to inform you that we had arrived here after many troubles we fined in Hedjaz. We fined every thing alright at Tor. We fined Dr. Roofer and Mahmoud Bey Rasmy, the Manor of Interior Ministry, very kind to us and other pilgrims, they always asking about the health, rest, food of Hodjazes. We fined Railway carry our baggage. Dear Sir, we ask your favour to write in your newspaper our thanks to the Egyptian Government. —Yours faithfuly servant, Kassim Hafeel Deen from Cape Town, South Africa. Tues, March 15,

On Tuesday aud Wednesday next there will be a lawn tennis (American) tournament, open to ladies only, singles and doubles, on the Ghezireh ground.

FOOTBALL. MINIEH v. SOHAG. Our Assiout Correspondent, writing on Friday last, says A football match took place to-day between the boys of the Minieh aud Sohag Government Schools. At 3.30 open. The game commenced in ilia playground of the American Mission School near the Assiout Barrage. More than two thousand people were present, among Whom were the Wekil of the Moudirieh; members of the Native Court and Parquet, and several notables of the town. An Inspector of the Finance Ministry aoted as Umpire. After an hour's fight the Minieh School boys won' by two goals to nil. ' it was noticed, however, that there w is a great difference in age between the hoy» of the two schools, those of Sohag not exceeding 12 or 14 years of age, while those >of Minieh had amongst them some ot 20 and 24 years. One of the Sohag boys was dangerously hurt in the eye and he was ordered fifteen duys’ medical treatment. At the end of the game the silver cup, awarded by the Ministry of Public Instruction to the winning team, was given to the Minieh boys amid shohta of ‘Hip, Hip, Hurrah.” Both teams afterwards left for their own towns in the hope of meeting here again next year.

TANTAH v. RAS-EL-TIN. A football match was played last Friday between Tantah and Has el-Tin Government School on Tantah playgrouud. Mr. Stewart, of the Finance Ministry, acted as referee aud the game was watched by many spectators. Kick ofi was at 3 p.m. and at half-time the Alexandria boys had scored four goals to uiL In the second half one more goal brought the result to 5 goals to nil. ttuch a brilliant victory caused great excitement among the Tantah boys, and consequently some disorder followed, but nothing serious happened owing to the efforts of the? Mamour of the Tantah City police, who succeeded in maintaining order.

AMATEUR ATHLETIC SPORTS. We would remind our readers of the Alexandria Amateur "Athletic Club's Spores, which will be held on the Sporting Club's ground (kindly granted for the occasion) on wednesday, April L2. The meeting, with the exception to the two open output is confined to members of the club. Membership may be obtained by early application to the hon. secretary, enclosing frames of proposer and seconder, who must be members of the club, k is hoped that the numerous athletes at present in Egypt will take advantage of this, the only athletic meeting in Alexandria. Entry forms may be had on application to the hon. secretary, Mr. R. B. McLean, Eastern Telegraph Co., Alexandria. div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: The weather is beginning to get warm. One European has already been a victim to sunstroke. The British S.S. “Bardistan” has arrived from England with a special consignment of material for the Sudan Railways, such, as iron bridges, wheels for locomotives, and sleepers, Also a large quantity of plaster of Paris (gypsum) for the Works Department at Bandar Sudan. Kaimakam Kennedy Bey, Director, Sudan Works Department, has gone to Sheikh . Barghoot for the purpose of planning opt the new town and road and other works. Kennedy Bey will be followed up by several Greek engineer contractors, who have previously worked for him at Khartoum, so as to seize the opportunity or work on the spot. When the tenders for work are issued.
